Trump has no infrastructure plans at all
See https://www.theatlantic.com/business/archive/2017/06/donald-trump-economic-policies/529554/?utm_medium=email&utm_source=newsletter&utm_term=170612&utm_campaign=ritholtz
Sure fooled me as well as Senator Feinstein, Merced and Fresno Newspapers A cautionary tale even reliable sources are unreliable in the neo-Orwellian world of DT "Consider the purported focus of this week. An infrastructure plan ought to include actual proposals, like revenue-and-spending details and timetables. The Trump infrastructure plan has little of that. Even the president’s speech on Monday was devoid of specifics. (An actual line was: “We have studied numerous countries, one in particular, they have a very, very good system; ours is going to top it by a lot.”) The ceremonial signing on Monday was pure theater. The president, flanked by politicians and businesspeople smiling before the twinkling of camera flashes, signed a paper that merely asks Congress to work on a bill. An assistant could have done that via email. Meanwhile, Congress isn’t working on infrastructure at all, according to Politico, and Republicans have shown no interest in a $200 billion spending bill. In short, this “plan” is not a plan, so much as a Potemkin policy, a presentation devised to show the press and the public that the president has an economic agenda. The show continued on Wednesday, as the president delivered an infrastructure speech in Cincinnati that criticized Obamacare, hailed his Middle East trip, and offered no new details on how his plan would work. Infrastructure Week is a series of scheduled performances to make it look as if the president is hard at work on a domestic agenda that cannot move forward because it does not exist." Fake news

The Trump administration announced Monday that it will fully fund a $650 million federal grant for electrification of a San Francisco Bay Area train system that also would help California’s high-speed rail project. The government previously delayed a decision when congressional Republicans objected. But the Federal Transit Administration said in a statement that the Caltrain project had “met all of the statutory requirements” for the funding. TLDR: The new CR, the one that takes us from 4/29 through 9/30/17, specifically appropriates bupkis to California High Speed Rail as a matter of law.  Slippery and subtle, these swamp creatures, but I think I've followed the spoor correctly.  Start at Congress.gov with the text of the last passed continuing resolution, the one from Friday 4/28/17.  
https://www.congress.gov/bill/115th-congress/house-joint-resolution/99/text It's only one page long, but it takes you here, the appropriations act from last September, which became public law back then and is the thing that is being continued:
https://www.gpo.gov/fdsys/pkg/PLAW-114publ223/pdf/PLAW-114publ223.pdf Search "rail" in the text, where you will find this: .   SEC 143.   (a)   Amounts   made   available   by   section   101   for  ‘‘Department of Transportation—Federal Railroad Administration— 
Operating  Grants  to  the  National  Railroad  Passenger  Corporation’’ and  ‘‘Department  of  Transportation—Federal  Railroad  Administra-
tion—Capital  and  Debt  Service  Grants  to  the  National  Railroad Passenger Corporation’’ shall be obligated in the account and budget 
structure,  and  under  the  authorities  and  conditions,  set  forth  for ‘‘Department of Transportation—Federal Railroad Administration— 
Northeast Corridor Grants to the National Railroad Passenger Corporation’’  and  ‘‘Department  of  Transportation—Federal  Railroad  
Administration—National Network Grants to the National Railroad Passenger  Corporation’’  in  H.R.  5394  and  S.  2844,  as  introduced  
in the One Hundred Fourteenth Congress That effectively enrolls the text from the June 2016 appropriations bills (HR 5394 and S2844 of the 114th congress) into the current resolution. Even though those two bills never passed their chambers, never even got out of committee, they now have the force of law until the end of September 2017.  Look up HR 5394 to find:   https://www.congress.gov/114/bills/hr5394/BILLS-114hr5394rh.pdf
and search for "California" to see: SEC.  192.  None  of  the  funds  made  available  by  this Act  may  be  used  for  high-speed  rail  in  the  State  of  California  or  for  the  California  High-Speed  Rail  Authority, nor may any be used by the Federal Railroad Administration  to  administer  a  grant  agreement  with  the  California High-Speed Rail Authority that contains a tapered matching requirement.  Just checking, look up S2844   https://www.congress.gov/114/bills/s2844/BILLS-114s2844pcs.pdf
and find that the text doesn't mention California rail at all.  In this way does the Congress enact into law appropriations bills that never got out of their respective committees and so were never debated publicly and never saw a vote of their chambers.  As Charlie Pierce likes to say: this is your America, my friend; cherish it.

Although this is an enormous infrastructure investment, the personal chemistry between Trump and California in general, and Trump and Brown in particular is too toxic for this project to have any legs. Also the lack of consensus within California about the merits of the project and the cost work against it. Someday it might well happen but not in the current political climate.

The project has long been vilified by congressional Republicans, particularly by House Majority Leader Kevin McCarthy (R-Bakersfield), who has called it a “boondoggle” that was “doomed to fail from the start.” And House rail subcommittee Chairman Jeff Denham (R-Turlock) has vowed to block any future federal funding for the project, citing long-standing concerns about its poor management controls and planning.

I think 25-1 odds are a fair starting point.  I don't want to underestimate the possibility that the Trump administration launches an all-out effort to fund infrastructure spending in the earliest months, as: 1) he appears to place a high priority on showing early action;  2) infrastructure spending is a high-probability way to fund jobs; and 3) some construction jobs would come with the project.  However, the opposition of the California Republican congressional delegation, the recent cost overruns, and the reports of lax cost controls ... and the resulting demands to audit the project .. are huge impediments to any federal funding being announced in the next 4 1/2 months.

Right now, the support in Washington is not there, and CA cannot afford to raise the funds alone to get the project done.  A good thing with poor support!

Highly doubtful. You might think that California's congressional delegation would want to harvest some pork from DC, but that isn't the case here. Most of the construction right now is in California's Central Valley, which sends most of California's Republicans to Congress. Here's a story from late last year: http://www.latimes.com/local/california/la-me-bullet-train-cash-20161224-story.html The upshot is that the two highest-ranking congressional Republicans from California - both from the Central Valley - want the project to be halted, and so will not press for any funding to be voted for the project by Congress. The Democrats might, but they won't be able to win a vote awarding funds. Since California gave Clinton the overwhelming majority of her popular vote win last November, Trump has no interest in releasing executive branch funds to reward the state. So it appears that nobody in the federal government has any incentive or desire to approve any new funding for the bullet train.
